My lecture is titled: Leaving Family to Join a Cult, Getting Out & Healing: The Power of Connection

When an individual joins a cult, it can be the case that so many others are affected beyond that individual. In 2001, at the age of 25, I joined a ‚Äúmystical christian‚Äù cult that I would remain in for 11 years. I was immediately targeted by the leaders as they sensed the close bond I had with my brother, mother, and father. This schism from my family would prove to be one of the greatest experiences of torture I would endure. But it was also this deep connection with family that seemed to shift from a bold rope that tied us all together, able to endure, until it slowly thinned into a frayed piece of string, constantly tugged on by the leaders of my group until it was a whisper of a web that I perceived as a glistening temptation of the past.
And then an awakening began to emerge, resulting from my question that arose against the messages I had been fed. I wondered for the first time in a long time, ‚ÄòWhy had I not communicated with my family in 8 years?‚Äô Any question of being attached had disappeared years ago with the puff of wind that sent the thin silky thread floating as a distant memory. This curiosity initiated my return to self and release from the group.

While the survivor stories of how we left are varied, the role that relational connections might play are often central to recovery, healing, or even survival. We will explore the power of this beyond my story. My hope is that this presentation provides relatable information for survivors, and helpful suggestions for friends and families with a loved one in a group of high control.

Pseudo-dictatorships, the implementation of strict rigid orders, and the admiration of leaders we can consider part of the ‚Äúelite‚Äù aren‚Äôt usually aspects one would associate with populism. So, what makes this form of populism different?

One thing authoritarian populist leaders such as Trump, Erdogan, or Viktor Orban, have specialized is appearing as PART of the people. They don‚Äôt speak as a representative of the people, for this would imply that they are superior to their subjects: instead they would passionately constantly claim themselves as part of the people. By acting in this way, the populace disassociates this leader from any elite backgrounds he might have, and considers him one of the pure people. This subsequently widens the power and scope of the populist leader, while weakening other aspects of the nation, such as the judicial and legislative branches of a country.

Authoritarian populist leaders also heavily utilize an ‚Äúenemy‚Äù: an ‚Äúopposing force to the pure people‚Äôs well being.‚Äù Depending on the nation, this populist leader would end up choosing an enemy which has impacted their people. However, this vilifying of a specific group or ideology is key in giving the populist leader greater power: he makes his people feel as though he is their protector, their savior, from these troubles.
